s.text: To my knowledge, Friedman's proposal has never struck anyone as fair, but at least it gets the incentives right.
As a result, corporations have little to fear from boycotts unless consumers commit themselves to maintaining the boycotts even when they serve no purpose.

That's an outcome that seems both fair and economically efficient: The punishment falls on the sinners and thereby deters the sin.

To my knowledge, Friedman's proposal has never struck anyone as fair, but at least it gets the incentives right.
And punishing evil corporations is very different from punishing evil governments.
From that perspective, the rabbi's analogy fails in a different way: The current owners of Daimler-Benz are not, by and large, the children of previous owners from half a century ago.
The entity that controls Chrysler is exactly the same entity that collaborated with the Nazis, not a descendant.
Suppose, for the sake of argument, that in 1950 it becomes foreseeable that Daimler-Benz will eventually make reparations.
